Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: At home, the child is learning daily manners, and the step-parent should provide guidance
Expectation2: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation2: An automated compliance system flags any minute of unscheduled downtime for possible disciplinary action.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, headset still around my neck, laptop open to the telemarketing dashboard. My stepdaughter, Emma, slouched across from me, poking at her food and mumbling. She’d just snapped at her little brother, and I knew I should step in—this was one of those moments to teach her about kindness and respect, the values I promised myself I’d help instill. But my break was almost over, and the compliance system at work was ruthless. If I didn’t log back in exactly on time, I’d get flagged again, and another warning could mean losing my job. Emma looked up, eyes searching for guidance, and I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in. I wanted to be the parent she needed, to talk her through her feelings and set boundaries, but the clock on my screen blinked, reminding me of the rules I couldn’t break. My heart pounded as I tried to decide which expectation I could afford to let down.
